column1: Pinewood Studios is an English film and television studio located in the village of Iver Heath in Buckinghamshire. It is approximately 20 miles (32 km) west of central London.The studio has been the base for many productions over the years from large-scale films to television programmes
column2: commercials
column3: and pop promos. It is well known as the home of the James Bond and Carry On film franchises.

column1: Pinewood Studios was built on the estate of Heatherden Hall
column2: a large Victorian country house which was purchased by Canadian financier
column3: and MP for Brentford and Chiswick
column4: Lt. Col. Grant Morden (1880–1932). He added refinements such as a ballroom
column5: a Turkish bath and an indoor squash court.  Due to its seclusion
column6: it was used as a discreet meeting place for high-ranking politicians and diplomats; the agreement to create the Anglo-Irish Treaty was signed there.

column2: building tycoon Charles Boot (1874–1945) bought the land and turned it into a country club.  The ballroom was converted into a restaurant and many of the bedrooms became furnished suites.

millionaire Methodist and flour magnate J. Arthur Rank (1888–1972) went into partnership with Boot and they transformed the estate into a film studio. Boot based designs for the studio complex on the latest ideas being employed by film studios in Hollywood
column3: California. Boot named the new studio Pinewood because "of the number of trees which grow there and because it seemed to suggest something of the American film centre in its second syllable". Construction began in December of that year
column4: with a new stage completed every three weeks. The studios were finished nine months later
column5: having cost £1 million (approx. £37 million at 2012 prices). Five stages were initially completed and there was provision for an enclosed water tank capable of holding 65
column8: which is still in use. In the years that followed

column1: The 1960s were buoyant years for Pinewood
column2: which was no longer solely dependent on the Rank Organisation to fill its stages. "Renters" (producers hiring the sound stages for a film-by-film agreement) were using half of the stages as Pinewood turned into a four walls facility. The James Bond franchise began at Pinewood with the Terence Young directed Dr. No (1962)
column3: and has continued to be based at the studios since then.

column1: J. Arthur Rank (by then Lord Rank) retired as chairman in 1962 and was succeeded by John Davis
column2: who had begun to move the Rank Organisation away from mass film production and towards more profitable and less risky businesses such as bingo and holidays.

column1: The 1970s were an uncertain period for Pinewood and the film industry in general
column2: with the studios being used more for television programmes
column3: including ITC Entertainment's UFO (1970)
column4: The Persuaders! (1971)
column5: starring Tony Curtis and Roger Moore

column1: The Rank Group owned the studio until 2001
column2: when it sold Pinewood to a group led by Michael Grade and Ivan Dunleavy. The purchase of Shepperton Studios from a consortium headed by Ridley and Tony Scott
column3: gave rise to the Pinewood Group
column4: eventually comprising Pinewood Studios
column5: Shepperton Studios
column11: and a joint venture in the US with Pinewood Atlanta Studios.

column2: Pinewood and Shepperton received a BAFTA Award for their Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema.

column1: The Pinewood Studios Group was subject to a hostile takeover approach in 2011. Manchester-based The Peel Group acquired a 73% stake
column2: but Warren James Jewellers retained a 27% stake
column3: so preventing a full takeover. As of 2012
column4: Pinewood's management is waiting to see if the Financial Services Authority would cancel the stock market listing in recognition of the fact that nearly all the shares are held by two groups. In June 2016
column5: five new stages and 10 new workshops were opened at Pinewood.The Walt Disney Studios announced a 10-year lease of most of the Pinewood Studios in September 2019

column1: The 007 Stage was originally built for the Bond film The Spy Who Loved Me (1977) and featured a massive water tank
column2: one of the largest in Europe. The stage was destroyed by fire in 1984; it was rebuilt four months later and renamed Albert R. Broccoli's 007 Stage in time for filming to commence on A View to a Kill. Another fire on 30 July 2006 seriously damaged the stage
column3: causing the roof to partly collapse. Construction of a new stage began on 18 September and was completed in under six months. Since then
column4: the stage has accommodated large productions including Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)
column5: Quantum of Solace (2008) and the whole fishing village from Mamma Mia! (2008) was built on the stage.

column2: Pinewood is situated on the old estate of Heatherden Hall which still stands today. The mansion
column3: its gardens and other parts of the studios have been used in various productions over the years. Peeping Tom (1960) shows people driving out through the main gate and has various shots in the studios (showing things behind the camera)
column4: offices and corridors. Return to the Edge of the World (1978) includes shots of director Michael Powell driving into the studio. The iconic main gate (now no longer used due to the construction of a purpose-built security entrance 500 m (1
column5: 600 ft) further along the road) also features in My Week with Marilyn (2011) when Eddie Redmayne greets Judi Dench. This film also contains many shots of the dressing-room corridors in the main make-up block. Heatherden Hall (converted to production offices) has appeared in several films: it was made to look fire-damaged and derelict for the children's film The Amazing Mr Blunden (1972) and also appeared as the Indian residence of Governor Sir Sidney Ruff-Diamond in Carry on up the Khyber (1969).

column1: The studios have acres of backlots where huge sets have been built
column2: from castles to whole villages including the Baker Street set built for Billy Wilder's  The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes and Godric's Hollow from the Harry Potter film series.

column1: The proximity of the ancient woodland Burnham Beeches and Black Park to Pinewood (as well as to Shepperton and Bray studios) and the outstanding natural beauty of the forest have made Burnham Beeches a desirable filming location for productions being filmed at Pinewood. Burnham Beeches has been used for a large number of films
column2: including Robin Hood Prince of Thieves
column3: First Knight
column4: Goldfinger
column5: The Princess Bride and Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
column6: Fahrenheit 451 at Black Park.  Many other films and TV productions have made use of the facilities on offer at the Beeches. (For a more comprehensive list

column1: The studios announced in April 2013 that its first film production facility in the United States would be located south of Atlanta at a complex consisting of 280 ha (690 acres) in Fayette County
column2: Georgia.

column1: Pinewood Atlanta is a joint venture between Pinewood and River's Rock LLC
column2: an independently managed trust of the Cathy family
column3: founders of the Chick-fil-A fast-food chain. The first production set to film at the studio was Marvel Studios' film Ant-Man in 2014.In August 2019
column4: Pinewood sold their shares in the Atlanta location. The studio officially ended its relationship with the location in October 2020 with the renaming of the studio to Trilith.

column1: Pinewood Iskandar Malaysia Studios is a studio complex located at a 20 ha (49 acres) site in Iskandar Puteri
column2: Johor
column3: managed by The Pinewood Studios Group. It targets the Asia-Pacific region. Pinewood Shepperton plc entered into a strategic agreement with Khazanah Nasional Berhad
column4: the investment holding arm of the Government of Malaysia in connection with the development of a new film and television studio facility in Iskandar Malaysia. Heavy investment is pouring into the region
column5: providing necessary funds for infrastructure projects and large business developments.

Pinewood announced a £200m expansion plan
column3: known as Project Pinewood. If built the development would see replicas of streetscapes and zones replicating locations from the UK

column1: Pinewood appealed against the decision and a public inquiry commenced on 5 April 2011 and on 20 January 2012

column4: Ivan Dunleavy
column5: said he expected to appeal against the latest decision to the Secretary of State
column8: a year earlier. On 19 June 2014 it was reported that Pinewood Studios had received approval to go ahead with the multimillion-pound expansion plans which would see it rival Hollywood film sets.

column1: Pinewood Studios is one of the sponsors for the short film competition Enter the Pitch
column2: also known as The Pitch
column3: which launched in 2009. The Pitch is an online short film pitching competition that invites film makers to submit a project that takes inspiration from any story
column4: character or theme in the Bible. The top ten finalists are taken to Pinewood Studios
column5: where they pitch their film to a panel of judges who are industry professionals. The person giving the winning pitch will win an apprenticeship with industry professionals and will be mentored on how to turn their pitch into a short film.
